title: Weak evidence and zero effect
text: A non-significant correlation means the data do not provide enough evidence to conclude that a real relationship exists in the population. It doesn’t mean the correlation is zero; just that we can’t rule out chance as an explanation.

hintAnswer: There is not enough evidence to conclude a real relationship exists
title: Evaluate evidence
text: If the result isn’t significant, what can we say about the evidence for the relationship? Does this prove there is no relationship, or just that we can’t detect one with this data?
choices: There is strong evidence of a real relationship
There is not enough evidence to conclude a real relationship exists
The evidence proves the correlation is exactly zero
The evidence shows the variables are completely unrelated

hintAnswer: It doesn’t prove there’s no $$relationship--it$$ just means we can’t detect one with the given data
title: Existence vs Detection
text: Does this prove there is no relationship, or just that we can’t detect one with this data?
choices: It proves absolutely that there is no relationship
It proves the relationship is strong but hidden
It doesn’t prove there’s no $$relationship--it$$ just means we can’t detect one with the given data
It proves the correlation must be negative

hintAnswer: Yes, a larger sample might provide enough power to detect a real relationship if one exists
title: Sample size impact
text: Could a larger sample size potentially make a difference?
choices: No, significance never depends on sample size
Yes, a larger sample might provide enough power to detect a real relationship if one exists
No, a larger sample always makes correlations weaker
Yes, but only if the correlation becomes exactly $$1.00$$.
